etymologies: late Middle English (in an earlier sense). Originally from either classical Latin perambulāre perambulate or post-classical Latin perambulatorium perambulatory, with the ending probably altered after amble

definitions: A long rambling tale or speech.
A walk, a ramble; a short excursion with no particular route or aim.

etymologies: late 15th century (in an earlier sense). From classical Latin perambulāre perambulate, with the ending probably altered after amble. Compare Middle French parambuler, perambuler

definitions: To wander or ramble in speaking. Now English regional (Lincolnshire regional).
